captions.text:
INTRO------
HI GUYS I’M CATIE WAYNE AND THIS IS ANIMALIST

NEWS!
FORGET ABOUT OWNING A COLLIE IN CHINA!

BEIJING OFFICIALS HAVE CREATED THE NATIONAL
COMPANION ANIMAL STANDARDIZATION COMMITTEE

IN HOPES OF CREATING STRICT NATIONAL GUIDELINES
ON WHICH DOG BREEDS CAN BE HOUSE PETS.

WHO WILL MAKE THE CUT?
YOUR GUESS IS PROBABLY AS GOOD AS MINE, BUT

PROBABLY NOT THE BREEDS YOU WOULD EXPECT.
LAST YEAR, BEIJING’S PUBLIC SECURITY BUREAU

ANNOUNCED THAT DOGS TALLER THAN FOURTEEN INCHES
WERE BANNED FROM THE COUNTRY’S CAPITAL.

THAT MEANS NO GERMAN SHEPHERDS, GOLDEN RETRIEVERS,
AND MANY OF THE WORLD’S MOST BELOVED BIG

DOGS!
ANOTHER FORTY ONE BREEDS, INCLUDING COLLIES,

HAVE BECOME ILLEGAL AFTER BEING LABELED AS
DANGEROUS.

A-K-A GOOD LUCK IF YOU FALL INTO A WELL IN
CHINA, BECAUSE LASSIE CAN’T COME TO YOUR

RESCUE.
WHILE THESE LAWS HAVE SO FAR BEEN LARGELY

IGNORED, CHINESE REGULATORS ARE DETERMINED
TO REGULATE THE ONE MILLION REGISTERED DOGS

THAT LIVE IN THE COUNTRY.
NOW A SERIES OF TESTS WILL BE PERFORMED ON

EACH BREED TO COMPARE BODY TYPES, DISPOSITION,
DISEASE RESISTANCE, AND EASE OF TRAINING.

AFTER THAT, BREEDS WILL BE CATEGORIZED AS
AGGRESSIVE, WORKING, ACTIVE, HUNTING, AND

SHEEP DOGS TO SUPPOSEDLY HELP FAMILIES AND
GOVERNMENT CHOOSE PETS.

AT THE END OF THE DAY, WHAT ARE OWNERS SUPPOSED
TO DO IF THEIR DOG IS TOO CUTE AND NOT DISEASE

RESISTANT ENOUGH?
THE PUBLIC SECURITY BUREAU SUGGESTS THAT ALL

OUTLAWED PETS SHOULD BE GIVEN TO SHELTERS.
WHAT DO YOU GUYS THINK? SHOULD GOVERNMENTS

BE ABLE TO BAN CERTAIN PETS?
LET ME KNOW IN THE COMMENTS BELOW!

BE SURE TO SUBSCRIBE AND CHECK OUT THESE OTHER
VIDEOS.
BYE!

comments.text:
I personally see absolutely nothing wrong with this.

why? because these laws mean that:
0:25 big dogs aren't allowed to suffer living in crowded cities, where they 
would be unable to get adequate exercise.


0:36 because dogs that are considered a dangerous have been banned. and 
rightfully so.


0:57 because dogs with hereditary diseases that are guaranteed to cause 
pain and suffering to the animal (and all subsequent generations of that 
animal) should not be allowed to be bred.


1:00 because the government will provide its citizens with a helpful list 
on dog breed characteristics, so that potential owners are less likely to 
choose a dog that does not suit their needs or wants? (much the same way as 
how western society has already categorized dogs into groups. e.g. Guard 
dog, sheep dog, lap dog, etc.)

there is ONE thing I found wrong in this video: 1:08
this argument about pets being "too cute and not disease resistant enough" 
is exactly how animal factories make a living.
who cares if the animals are likely to suffer? who cares if they are bred 
en-mass, most of which will never find a home to go to? as long as there is 
a market for "cute" pets, there will always be an opening for animal 
factories.﻿
comments.author: Shane Rooney

comments.text:
two options:
Option 1) have a government that bans some breeds based on what is best for

Option 2) have a government that will allow any dog to be bred. including 
breeds of dogs with a tendency towards violence, or Dogs that suffer from 
hereditary diseases. Not to mention that these dogs are then often bread in 
'animal factories' enmass.﻿

comments.author: Shane Rooney

comments.text:
"Besides, training a fox is impossible because they're wild animals" -- 
EXACTLY !!! some species of animals are harder to train than others, even 
to the point of being impossible to train. Hence why some breeds of dogs 
should be allowed to be domesticated while other breeds shouldn't be. Hench 
the laws coming into effect in China.
comments.author: Shane Rooney

comments.text:
+Shane Rooney They're still not dogs. Foxes are more closely related to the 
ancestors of both cats and dogs than dogs. Besides, training a fox is 
impossible because they're *wild animals*, not because they are foxes. One 
of the primary drivers for domesticating animals (such as dogs) is to make 
it possible to train them.
comments.author: Corinn Heathers

comments.text:
+Corinn Heathers, after reading my entire post the only reply you could 
think of was that? and even then your counter argument is questionable at 
best. both 'dogs' and 'foxes' are from the Canidae biological family, and 
what seporates one from the other is more to do with naming convention than 
specific genetic traits. (Wikipedia "The traditional subdivision of Canidae 
into "foxes" and "true dogs" may not be in accordance with the actual 
relations....")
comments.author: Shane Rooney

comments.text: +Shane Rooney Foxes aren't dogs, so your comparison fails.
comments.author: Corinn Heathers

comments.text:
+Caitlyn Cooper. thanks for your reply, However I disagree with a lot of 
what you said.

.

 "no dog breed is specifically more dangerous than the next."
an interesting claim. how do you back it up.....

"Some have more powerful jaws and aggressive breed traits"
... oh, that's how. But wouldn't "aggressive breed traits" make the dog 
more inclined towards violence, and thus be considered "more dangerous"?
I would really like you to clarify your definitions here, because as far as 
I can see you are contradicting yourself.

.


"hereditary disease do not guarantee suffering."
I agree that they do not *guarantee* suffering. but they certainly increase 
its likelihood.

"Banning an entire breed over common health problems is overkill."
A subjective opinion. why I disagree with this opinion is explained below

"It is improper breeding that caused the problems, and proper care and 
selective breeding can prevent them."
it is improper breeding that caused these *breeds* in the first place. And 
'selective breeding' in this case involves a panel of experts being hired 
by the government to conduct a multi-year long survey in order to 'select' 
which dogs should be breed and which shouldn't be.

.

" but it should still be the right of the person to chose what breed to 
allow in his life."
they can choose, but only from a limited list of pre-approved breeds.
And before you get all indignant, and start saying how 'western countries' 
have more freedom; Don't western countries also have laws about what type 
of animals can and can't be had as a pet? (the answer is yes, they do)

I am sure you would be allowed to have a big dog living in a crowded city 
(despite the dog being unsuited to the city), But why not a trained pig? 
shouldn't the people be allowed to choose from ANY animal?
why do you need a license to own a snake? (I am not sure about the US, but 
that is certainly the case in Australia)

.

"she is still the kindest, most docile dog you will ever meet, and all 
because I trained her properly"
try training a fox.

the whole nature vs. nurture argument is pointless.
there are very good reasons why Tibetan Mastiffs are bred for guard dogs 
and why Labradors are bred for family pets. Because instincts will ALWAYS 
play a role.

True, with adequate training you *might* be able to override the 
animals instincts. but at end of the day, the instincts are still there for 
the next generation to inherit.
it is better to breed quiet docile dogs than it is to breed yap-yap 
annoying dogs or violent territorial dogs (unless you want a guard dog, in 
that case breed a Tibetan Mastiff).
comments.author: Shane Rooney

comments.text:
+Shane Rooney First off, no dog breed is specifically more dangerous than 
the next. Some have more powerful jaws and aggressive breed traits, but all 
breeds can be trained properly to prevent danger. That's what domestication 
is. Also, hereditary disease do not guarantee suffering. Banning an entire 
breed over common health problems is overkill. It is improper breeding that 
caused the problems, and proper care and selective breeding can prevent 
them. And it's all good and well that China wants to help provide their 
citizens with ideal companions for their lifestyles, but it should still be 
the right of the person to chose what breed to allow in his life.
 I have a siberian husky, a breed bred for physical activity, while living 
in the suburbs. Even though she is not getting the same exercise that she 
could in a more rural area, she is still the kindest, most docile dog you 
will ever meet, and all because I trained her properly. There are no "bad 
breeds," only bad owners.
comments.author: Caitlyn Cooper

wrote it -.-
